description: From Middle English disposicioun, from Middle French disposition, from Latin dispositiōnem, accusative singular of dispositiō, from dispōnō; surface analysis, dispose +‎ -ition. Doublet of dispositio.

definitionGroups.group: The way in which something or someone is disposed or disposed of (in any sense of those terms); thus:

entries.meaning: Control over something, or the results produced by the exercise of such control; thus:
examples: The scouts reported on the disposition of the enemy troops.

entries.meaning: The arrangement or placement of certain things.
examples: The scouts reported on the disposition of the enemy troops.

entries.meaning: Control over something, especially with regard to disposing or dispensing with an action item (disposal of a concern, allocation of disbursed funds) or control over the arrangement or placement of certain things.
examples: You will have full disposition of these funds.

entries.meaning: (law) Transfer or relinquishment to the care or possession of another.
examples: The court ordered the disposition of all assets.
The disposition of the case will be announced tomorrow.

entries.meaning: (medicine) The destination of a patient after medical treatment, especially after emergency triage, first line treatment, or surgery; the choice made for the next venue of care.
examples: The patient was given a disposition for outpatient care, as ward admission was not indicated.

entries.meaning: (music) The set of choirs of strings on a harpsichord.
examples: This small harpsichord has a 1 x 4' disposition.

entries.meaning: Tendency or inclination under given circumstances.
examples: I have little disposition now to do as you say.
Salt has a disposition to dissolve in water.
He has such a foul disposition.

verbs.description: disposition (third-person singular simple present dispositions, present participle dispositioning, simple past and past participle dispositioned)

entries.meaning: To remove or place in a different position.
